source.57581afa:
import numpy as np
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
def plotWordFrequency(input):
    f = open(ukrainian_file,'r')
    words = [x for y in [l.split() for l in f.readlines()] for x in y]
    data = sorted([(w, words.count(w)) for w in set(words)], key = lambda x:x[1], reverse=True)[:40] 
    most_words = [x[0] for x in data]
    times_used = [int(x[1]) for x in data]
    plt.figure(figsize=(20,10))
    plt.bar(x=sorted(most_words), height=times_used, color = 'green', edgecolor = 'black',  width=.5)
    plt.xticks(rotation=45, fontsize=18)
    plt.yticks(rotation=0, fontsize=18)
    plt.xlabel('Most Common Words:', fontsize=18)
    plt.ylabel('Number of Occurences:', fontsize=18)
    plt.title('Most Commonly Used Words: %s' % (ukrainian_file), fontsize=24)
    plt.show()
source.9991237e:
#Lesya Ukrainka(Ukrainian: Леся Українка)

Born Larysa Petrivna Kosach-Kvitka (Ukrainian: Лариса Петрівна Косач-Квітка) (February 25 O.S. February 13) 1871 – August 1 (O.S. July 19 1913) is one of Ukrainian literature's foremost writers, best known for her poems and plays. She was also an active political, civil, and feminist activist. 
Among her most well-known works are the collections of poems On the wings of songs (1893), Thoughts and Dreams (1899), Echos (1902), the epic poem Ancient fairy tale (1893), One word (1903), plays Princess (1913), Cassandra (1903—1907), In the Catacombs (1905), and Forest song (Lisova Pisnya 1911). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lesya_Ukrainka
source.fa302b13:
#Once Upon a Time There Lived Mavkas.., by Дарина Дар 

Ancient Slavic mythology is rich in fantastic creatures. One particularly interesting and misterious group of these creatures, the mavkas, have even inspired the great Ukrainian poetess Lesya Ukrainka to write her immortal poem "Lisova pisnya" ("Forest Song"). Lisova Pisnya is poem by Lesya Ukrainka.

Mavkas were little children who either died unbaptized, were killed by their mothers, or were children who died during the so called "Mermaids week" (the week after Trinity when according to Slavic mythology, mermaids walk the earth). It was believed that after death mermaids took these children.
https://uamodna.com/en/articles/pro-mavku-promovka/
